etymology.description: 餛(馄) (hún, "mix; confused") and 飩(饨) (tún, "swallow; round food") together refer to a type of dumpling with mixed ingredients inside, typically boiled and served in soup.
etymology.interpretation: The word 馄饨(餛飩) (húntun, "wonton") describes a dumpling with various ingredients inside, represented by the notion of mixing in 餛(馄) (hún, "mix; confused"). The 饨(飩) (tún, "swallow; round food") highlights its round shape and that it is meant to be eaten whole, often served in soup.

examples.chinese: 早餐吃馄饨(餛飩)，营养丰富(營養豐富)。
examples.pinyin: Zǎocān chī hún tún, yíngyǎng fēngfù.
examples.english: Having wonton for breakfast makes it nutritious.

examples.chinese: 他在街角的摊位买馄饨(餛飩)，味道极佳(味道極佳)。
examples.pinyin: Tā zài jiējiǎo de tānwèi mǎi hún tún, wèidào jí jiā.
examples.english: He buys wonton at the street corner stall; the taste is excellent.
